TypeSignature.Value: .class nested protected auto ansi beforefieldinit WeakEventManager/ListenerList extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides a built-in collection list for storing listeners for a .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Although this list contains members that resemble those defined by and , and provide similar functionality, this class implements neither of those interfaces. Most derived classes do not need to use any members on . The methods and use a default internally, one list for each `source`. You only need to call methods if your class maintains multiple lists for the same event-source combination, with each list created to account for different conditions of the event. In this case, you would not use and and would instead implement `AddListener` or `RemoveListener` to act upon listeners in just one of the internal listener lists, typically based on a parameter that you add to `AddListener` or `RemoveListener`. Also, the handler implementation that receives the raw event cannot simply call ; you must instead keep track of the specifics of the event and deliver the event only to the appropriate list using . The various methods of are provided so that you can work with your internal lists and so that you can prevent modification of the list during actual delivery of the event. An example class that used this implementation technique is , which maintains separate listener lists for `PropertyChanged` based on which property changed. ## XAML Text Usage You cannot use this class in [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_xaml](~/includes/tla2sharptla-xaml-md.md)].

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Add(class System.Windows.IWeakEventListener listener) cil managed

Docs.param: The listener element to add to the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The object provided as listener should be a <xref:System.Windows.DependencyObject> that implements the <xref:System.Windows.IWeakEventListener> interface and therefore has a working <xref:System.Windows.IWeakEventListener.ReceiveWeakEvent%2A> implementation.
You should always call <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> before changing the list contents. Otherwise, the list may be in process of delivering events and therefore the original is locked. Calling <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> changes the input `list` to be a clone so that your <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.Add%2A> call can still work on the clone. If <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> returns `true`, you might need to update any private references to the list that you maintain in other areas of your code.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void AddHandler(class System.Delegate handler) cil managed

Docs.param: The event handler to add to the .
Docs.summary: Adds an event handler to the .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance bool BeginUse() cil managed

Docs.summary: Declares the list to be in use. This prevents direct changes to the list during iterations of the list items.
Docs.returns: if the list was already declared to be in use; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager> implementation should call <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.BeginUse%2A> before iterating through the list to deliver an event to the listeners, and should call <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.EndUse%2A> when it is done. This prevents another caller from modifying the list while the iteration for purposes of event delivery is in progress. If the list is modified during this time, then the list is cloned. If the list is cloned, then <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> returns `true`, which means that you have missed a recent listener change in the last delivery.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that declares whether this is empty.
Docs.value: if the list is empty; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method is equivalent to checking whether the <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.Count%2A> is zero, and does not check whether any of the references in the list are now stale. If you want to assure that all references are still valid, call <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.Purge%2A> just prior to checking the empty status of the list.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig bool PrepareForWriting(class System.Windows.WeakEventManager/ListenerList& list) cil managed
Public Shared Function PrepareForWriting (ByRef list As WeakEventManager.ListenerList) As Boolean

Docs.param: The list to check for use state and potentially copy.
Docs.summary: Checks to see whether the provided list is in use, and if so, sets the list reference parameter to a copy of that list rather than the original.
Docs.returns: if the provided list was in use at the time of call and therefore the parameter reference was reset to be a copy. if the provided list was not in use, in which case the parameter reference remains unaltered.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the given list is in use (which means an event is currently being delivered), calling this method will replace the input `list` with a clone. The existing users will finish delivering the event to the original list, without interference from changes to the new list.
If the method returns `true`, callers may want to insert the new list in their own data structures, since this indicates the possibility that the provided list is no longer current.
This method calls <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.BeginUse%2A> internally and then immediately calls <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.EndUse%2A>. Therefore calling <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> does not itself introduce a lock on the list. Even the clone copy is done as a secondary operation after calling <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.EndUse%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance bool Purge() cil managed

Docs.summary: Removes all entries from the list where the underlying reference target is a null reference.
Docs.returns: Returns if any entries were purged; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Remove(class System.Windows.IWeakEventListener listener) cil managed

Docs.summary: Removes the first occurrence of a listener item from the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks You should always call <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> before changing the list contents. Otherwise, the list may be in process of delivering events and therefore the original is locked. Calling <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> changes the input `list` to be a clone so that your <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.Remove%2A> call can still work on the clone. If <xref:System.Windows.WeakEventManager.ListenerList.PrepareForWriting%2A> returns `true`, you might need to update any private references to the list that you maintain in other areas of your code.
